captions.text:
Metaphor: ReFantazio (I think
that&#39;s how you pronounce that)
is a brand new IP from the Persona devs.
&quot;At last!&quot; they must&#39;ve cried.

&quot;We&#39;re free of churning out
JRPG life simulator hybrids!

Let&#39;s finally pursue our dream of
making a JRPG life simulator hybrid

that&#39;s called something different.&quot;
Uh-huh. Take it you got sick of
waiting for the Persona 6 greenlight.

&quot;How dare you, Yahtz, didn&#39;t you notice we
changed the names of SOME of the spells?

So now the fire spell is
called BOT instead of AGI.&quot;
I guess that makes more sense;

I, for one, have never had a
fiery AGI after a lamb vindaloo.

&quot;Also, our new game is
set in a fantasy world,

which I guess doesn&#39;t change much besides
decreasing your chances of getting laid.&quot;
Yeah, I was gonna bring that up.

Considering the Persona
devs have never seen

a &quot;perving on the girls in the bath&quot;
scene they didn&#39;t like, Metaphor
has a surprising lack of horniness.
Well, having said that, it is anime,

so there&#39;s still the
default amount of horn;

your support character is a fairy
in severe need of trousers,

and the first female party
member wears leggings so tight

she couldn&#39;t take them off without
turning her birth canal inside out.

But there&#39;s no romancing your social
contacts, no gratuitous swimsuit chapter,

and the only bath is a frumpy
wooden bucket that your character

sits in by himself like a puppy confused
about how his water bowl works.
Talk about losing your lust for waif. Oo.

The fantasy setting loses
some of the stylishness

that came with Persona&#39;s
groovy, trendy modern setting.

Yes, there&#39;s still a lot of flair
in the interface and shit,

but the monsters are mostly generic
goblins, dragons, wolves, etc.

that don&#39;t the slightest bit resemble
the subconscious demons of sex pest

volleyball teachers, and the battle
music, instead of being, say,

the best fucking song in
the history of audible sound,

is more a generic bombastic
orchestral affair with a vocal track

that sounds like an opera singer
falling down a very long staircase.

So it&#39;s a much less sexy affair
across the board, I’m afraid,
and yet still has the spirit of Persona

because you have to play
it for about eight hours

to get to what the game&#39;s
actually fucking about.
Here&#39;s the CliffsNotes.

The fantasy world&#39;s population is
split between multiple tribes

that are all super racist
against each other.

They&#39;re all pretty anime people,
it&#39;s just some have cat ears,

some have elf ears,
some have sparkly eyes;

nothing that&#39;d put you off
buying their big-titty mousepads.

In this time of turmoil, a gigantic
anime bastard in the usual model—pale,

smug voice, looks a bit like
Farrah Fawcett—murders

the king and curses the
prince to eternal sleep.
As the prince&#39;s childhood friend,

you join a secret mission to
assassinate the anime bastard

as he&#39;s trying to seize power and
thus break the prince&#39;s curse,

but just before you can stab
him, a fuckoff giant stone dad

appears in the sky and goes, &quot;Hey! None of
that coup d&#39;état and assassination rubbish.
We&#39;re doing this properly or not at all.

Whoever has the most public support
in about six months gets to be king.

And I&#39;m gonna keep watching for any funny
business.&quot; Well, this was unexpected.
Magic dad-enforced democracy.

So one major dungeon later, we and
our party load onto a fucking tour bus

and must go around the country
solving problems and building support
on behalf of the comatose prince

as the anime bastard and various
third parties do the same.

And that&#39;s what the game&#39;s actually fucking
about: campaign trailing during election season.
Gosh, this is fucking timely, isn&#39;t it?
I particularly like the part

where the insane dude who blatantly
tried to seize power in a violent coup

still somehow has about half the
country&#39;s popular support.

The usual Persona time management
gameplay ensues, with you splitting

your days between dungeon
crawling, building relationships,

and doing activities that up your
social stats, namely in this case,

Courage, Imagination, Wisdom,
Eloquence, and Tolerance, implying that

the protagonist starts out as a cowardly,
boring, ignorant, inarticulate racist.
Ooh! Even more timely.

Full disclosure, I haven&#39;t had
time to finish the game,

&#39;twas ever thus with JRPGs,
but I&#39;m really hoping it

turns out we were the prince all
along, or another legitimate heir,

&#39;cos after we&#39;ve done all the bloody work
to become the people&#39;s choice for king
seems a bit dumb to then go,

&quot;Psych! I&#39;m abdicating in favor of someone
who&#39;s been comatose since childhood.

I hear you learn a lot about
statecraft from pissing in a tube.&quot;

How Metaphor differs from Persona
is that you don&#39;t have Personas.

That&#39;s why it&#39;s called Metaphor:
RePhantasmabollocks and not
and not Persona: Narnia Edition.
Instead, you have Archetypes,

a fairly complicated concept;
let me think how to explain.

It&#39;s...the job system
from Final Fantasy 5.

Oh. Less complicated
than I thought, actually.

Every character you can befriend
in your chaste, unsexy way is

associated with a class that can be
assigned to your party members.

The Warrior, the Mage, the
Ice Cream Salesman, etc.

The more experience
they gain in that role

and the more you befriend
the associated character,

the more skills they acquire. Gosh,
with four such versatile party members,
I&#39;ll be able to meet any challenge.

Hey, why does my meeting
table have eight chairs?

Yes, I question the necessity
of all the reserve party members

the story forces onto you when, with smart
enough job swapping, all you need is two

strength guys, two magic guys,
and everyone else holds the coats.

Like Persona, combat&#39;s all about
ambushing and exploiting weaknesses.

There&#39;s a real-time combat
element, marginally;

you have a basic attack and dodge
while in dungeon-explorey mode,

and if you&#39;re fighting lower-level
enemies, they&#39;ll just die right

there, swiftly fading away as tacit
apology for wasting your time.

Everyone else, hit them and you&#39;re
teleported to classic turn-based

battle world with a little
visual and orchestral orgasm.

Take them by surprise in real-time
mode, and the enemy starts with lower

health, stunned, and with their
trousers &#39;round their ankles.

On the other hand, if they ambush you,
you might as well leg it and try again

because again, like Persona, if a standard
enemy ever lands a hit on you at all,

you&#39;ve already fucked up, and they&#39;ll swiftly
bog you down with weakness exploits

and status ailments before
you can pull your trousers up.

The monsters are noticeably lacking
in variety, and the optional side quest
dungeons are kinda samey as well.

I say optional; you have to do them
to keep from getting underlevelled,
and anyway, they&#39;re more interesting

than sitting around the tour bus,
working on your bean-flicking stat.

What makes Metaphor interesting is the
emphasis on the road trip aspect—when you&#39;re

planning to hit dungeons, you
have to factor in travel time

so you don&#39;t arrive on a day
when the weather is bad

and the enemies all have an extra nark
on from the copy-pasted wolf packs
smelling like wet dog.

We also stop at natural beauty spots
to grab postcards for stock proxy

little sister character A,
which I do like as
world-stroke-character-building moments.

Do I like Metaphor: Randy
Andy Pants generally?
I guess so.

I like Persona, and this
feels like Persona,

just with some of the gameplay
wires crossed differently.

But it&#39;s less stylish and falls back
on the typical JRPG formula more.
Fantasy setting. Airships.

Here&#39;s the desert bit, here&#39;s the ocean
journey bit, here&#39;s the tropical island

bit—that gave me a laugh &#39;cos we
meet this exotic tribe of islanders

considered by the rest of the world
to be incomprehensible savages,

and they convey that in the English
dub by giving them Welsh accents.
Yeah, real fucking exotic, guys.

They&#39;re big on ritualistic human
sacrifice in fuckin&#39; Cardiff.

Well, they are if you
slag off the rugby team.
